title: 109_s1695
content: The Act is titled the "Hurricane Katrina Food Assistance Relief Act of 2005" and defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture. It also addresses the Food Stamp Program Disaster Authority. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include a response to Hurricane Katrina, defining "affected area" as regions impacted by the hurricane or related conditions. This amendment falls under the Hurricane Katrina Food Assistance Relief Act of 2005. The Hurricane Katrina Food Assistance Relief Act of 2005 defines "affected household" as a household in an affected area where a member worked prior to August 29, 2005, or was displaced due to a major disaster or emergency designation. The Hurricane Katrina Food Assistance Relief Act of 2005 defines "affected household" as a household containing individuals displaced by Hurricane Katrina or a related condition, as determined by the Secretary. The term 'disaster recovery period' is defined as 180 days from the date of enactment, extendable for another 180 days if needed. During this period, certain clauses do not apply to affected households. During the disaster recovery period, procedures for affected households include increased value of the thrifty food plan by 10%, payment of administrative costs to State agencies, and meeting requirements for assistance. During the disaster recovery period, affected households may qualify for assistance if their income does not exceed the permitted level by more than 50%. Resources lost due to Hurricane Katrina are not considered financial resources, and funds designated for rebuilding or relocation are excluded from eligibility considerations. During the disaster recovery period, affected households may qualify for assistance if their income does not exceed the permitted level by more than 50%. Eligibility criteria include not customarily purchasing food and preparing meals with others before August 29, 2005, and treating lawfully present immigrants the same as refugees for eligibility purposes. Duplicate participation is not allowed. During the disaster recovery period, the Secretary will identify and terminate duplicate participation of affected households in multiple states. No action will be taken against households for duplicate participation during the recovery period unless deliberate falsehoods are involved. Claims relating to benefits cannot be established unless intentional program violations are determined. During the disaster recovery period, the Secretary will disregard errors in payment rates caused by certain provisions. More generous disaster plans approved under the Food Stamp Act of 1977 will not be superseded by this paragraph. Program information activities will be funded from existing funds for the food stamp program. The Secretary may use up to $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2005-2006 to contract with nonprofit organizations to address food assistance needs after Hurricane Katrina. No public notice or competitive bids are required for these contracts. SEC. 4. Emergency food assistance program and Section 32 assistance. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of an "eligible recipient" for assistance related to Hurricane Katrina, including individuals or households affected by the hurricane or displaced by it. Additionally, it mentions the allocation of funds for the emergency food assistance program. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer $200,000,000 to the Secretary of Agriculture for providing food assistance to eligible recipients, including special supplemental foods for pregnant women and infants, infant formula, bottled water, and fruit juices. The funds can be used to provide commodities in accordance with specific acts. The Secretary of Agriculture will receive $200,000,000 from the Secretary of the Treasury for food assistance, in addition to funds from section 32 of the Act of August 24, 1935. The funds will be used to provide food assistance to eligible recipients as specified in the legislation. SEC. 5. CHILD NUTRITION PROGRAMS. The disaster recovery period defined in this section is 180 days, extendable for another 180 days if deemed necessary by the President. The Secretary has the authority to modify assistance conditions for child nutrition programs in consultation with relevant officials. During the disaster recovery period, temporary food assistance is provided to households affected by a disaster under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966. During the disaster recovery period, temporary food assistance is provided to households affected by a disaster under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966. WIC funding is addressed in Section 6. The Treasury will transfer $200,000,000 to the Secretary of Agriculture for the special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children. The funds are designated as an emergency requirement. The Secretary of Agriculture will allocate emergency funds to provide assistance to women, infants, and children affected by Hurricane Katrina or related conditions, as determined in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 7. COMMODITY SUPPLEMENTAL FOOD PROGRAM FUNDING. The Secretary of the Treasury shall transfer $20,000,000 to the Secretary of Agriculture for the commodity supplemental food program. The funds are designated as an emergency requirement and shall be used without further appropriation. The Secretary will allocate funds to assist individuals affected by Hurricane Katrina or related conditions, as determined in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, consulting with the Secretary of Homeland Security. The report will address the need for additional funding or authority to support eligible recipients and any determination by the President regarding the extension of the disaster recovery period. Additionally, regulations will be established. The Secretary may issue necessary regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedural requirements. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted using specific authority provided.
